profileText: A Representative from Indiana; born in Pike County, Ohio, February 18, 1842; studied law; was admitted to the bar and practiced; during the Civil War served in the Union Army from May 1861 to December 1865, except three months in 1863, attached to the Fourteenth Iowa Infantry and the Twelfth Indiana Cavalry; took up his residence in La Porte, Ind.; State's attorney for the ninth Indiana judicial circuit 1866-1870; member of the State house of representatives in 1871; elected as a Republican to the Forty-fifth and to the three succeeding Congresses and served from March 4, 1877, to October 20, 1884, when he resigned; chairman, Committee on Elections (Forty-seventh Congress); moved to Tacoma, Wash., and resumed the practice of law; appointed United States associate justice of the Territory of Washington in April 1889 and served until November 11, 1889, when the Territory was admitted as a State into the Union; died in Tacoma, Wash., on January 29, 1894; interment in Tacoma Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Calkins, William H. Speech of Hon. William H. Calkins, of Indiana, in the House of Representatives, May 10, 1880. [Washington: Government Printing Office, 1880].

researchRecord.name: 1863-1930, 15 items.
researchRecord.description: The collection contains 5 letters from Benjamin Harrison regarding politics in Indiana and in Washington, D.C. There are also letters to William Calkins from Chester A. Arthur, William Tecumseh Sherman, James Whitcomb Riley, and John Marcus Dickey regarding James Whitcomb Riley. Also includes 2 letters from Booth Tarkington to Mrs. Calkins concerning remembrances about Indianapolis, as well as invitations to meet the Prsident of the United States.

researchRecord.name: In the W.R. Holloway Papers, 1824-1899, 5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include William H. Calkins. A finding aid is available in the repository.
